text: the neutral credit you would have to receive for this to have a 5050 probability a zero sum over the long run is 31 cents you are collecting 23 cents you are nowhere near where you need to be in order to capture a neutral credit this is using again dollar wide 35 days to expiration so you might say well what about 3D pte what if we go shorter term same same this is a dollar wide collecting 19 the problem with most of these is that they are not going to be priced favorably to you that's by Design so even if you look at wider spreads let's say 5 wide 10 wide you're going to find the same thing in general you are not even going to be able to capture a neutral credit trade let alone something that has any sort of positive expectation baked into this so what does that mean well it means that you would have to get really really good at trading directionally right because this is a bullish strategy in this case when we're talking about the put credit spreads if you're trading call Credit spreads it would be bearish and in those instances there are much better ways to express that hypothesis than these so what does this all amount to death by 1,000 paper cuts you're not going to blow up on anyone's single trade which is actually a great component to these however you're not really going to

text: in those instances there are much better ways to express that hypothesis than these so what does this all amount to death by 1,000 paper cuts you're not going to blow up on anyone's single trade which is actually a great component to these however you're not really going to make any money on them as you're trading them which is unfortunate because I came across them they were touted as some sort of really great approach for small accounts and then I was thinking oh man I'm winning a lot this is great then I started looking at the numbers in the long run when I started taking this stuff more seriously and I was just like oh I'm not doing anything here other than racking up commissions so this is the big problem with them they are deceptive you will win a lot very small amount of money each time you are paying way too much in terms of the friction for commissions and even the spread because you have two legs that you're dealing with so like I promised you what are some of the Alternatives well if you're bullish this is what I would do the covered strangle ratio covered calls ratio call diagonals buying shares you could even buy calls if you want and I have videos that talk through literally all of these which I will throw them in the notes below for you they all have their drawbacks a lot of these are

text: covered strangle ratio covered calls ratio call diagonals buying shares you could even buy calls if you want and I have videos that talk through literally all of these which I will throw them in the notes below for you they all have their drawbacks a lot of these are more expensive so you're going to have to pick products very carefully they're not as efficient you're not going to have as great return on invested Capital however you can create better expectant strategies using these structures now looking if you're bearish again just a few ideas you can trade ratio put diagonals long puts both of those are completely fine or if you're trading volatility outright AKA I want to capture variance risk premiums you can trade short straddles short strangles I have videos in the notes Below on those as well and again for any of these if you have to buy the wings either to protect catastrophic loss the idea here is to go much further out of the money so that you are not giving up as much of the credit you're receiving specifically for vertical credit spreads again there's no free lunch here that's the problem that's the uncomfortable reality of trading options is just because vertical credit spreads or what are accessible to you it doesn't mean they're good there's a reason why you're not going to see a lot of Pros trading these and it's because of these reasons they're inefficient they really
